articles.headline: Chinese Economic Juggernaut Is Gaining on Japan
articles.snippet: Many economists expect China to replace Japan as the world’s second-largest economy next year, five years earlier than previously forecast.
articles.abstract: Many economists expect China to replace Japan as the world’s second-largest economy next year, five years earlier than previously forecast.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  For years, Japan has been readying itself for the day that it is eclipsed economically by China. But as a result of the global slowdown, Japan’s difficulty in managing its economy and China’s rise  on vivid display Thursday as Beijing celebrated the 60th anniversary of the founding of the People’s Republic  that day may come sooner than anyone predicted.

articles.headline: Senator’s Aid After Affair Raises Flags Over Ethics
articles.snippet: Senator John Ensign may have violated ethics laws by helping an aide after having an affair with his wife.
articles.abstract: Senator John Ensign may have violated ethics laws by helping an aide after having an affair with his wife.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Early last year, Senator John Ensign contacted a small circle of political and corporate supporters back home in Nevada — a casino designer, an airline executive, the head of a utility and several political consultants — seeking work for a close friend and top Washington aide, Douglas Hampton.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: In NBC Universal Bid, Comcast Seeks an Empire
articles.snippet: The cable company is said to be in negotiations with General Electric to create a separate company, merging Comcast’s programming assets with NBC Universal.
articles.abstract: The cable company is said to be in negotiations with General Electric to create a separate company, merging Comcast’s programming assets with NBC Universal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Five years after Comcast’s failed bid for the Walt Disney Company, Brian L. Roberts is again looking to fulfill his long-sought dream of turning his cable company into a major media conglomerate.
articles.byline: By Bill Carter and Brian Stelter

articles.headline: Rich and Poor Should Pay Same Price
articles.snippet: It seems absurd to have a system that requires people who do not use credit to subsidize those who do.
articles.abstract: It seems absurd to have a system that requires people who do not use credit to subsidize those who do.
articles.lead_paragraph: What would you think of a proposal to create a consumer financial system in which the poor subsidize the well off? How about one that raises costs for those who do not use credit while imposing hefty penalties on those who use it unwisely?

articles.headline: Lewis Still Faces a Gantlet of Legal and Political Woes
articles.snippet: Inquiries loom over the bank’s purchase of Merrill Lynch, and the role that Kenneth D. Lewis and other executives played in not disclosing losses and bonus payouts.
articles.abstract: Inquiries loom over the bank’s purchase of Merrill Lynch, and the role that Kenneth D. Lewis and other executives played in not disclosing losses and bonus payouts.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is no easy exit for Kenneth D. Lewis.

articles.headline: Who Can Take Charge at Bank of America?
articles.snippet: The Dec. 31 departure of Kenneth D. Lewis has left the board at Bank of America scrambling for a successor.
articles.abstract: The Dec. 31 departure of Kenneth D. Lewis has left the board at Bank of America scrambling for a successor.
articles.lead_paragraph: Who will lead Bank of America out of this mess?
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Louise Story

articles.headline: Jobs Report Highlights Shaky U.S. Recovery
articles.snippet: The report showed a loss of 263,000 jobs last month and reinforced a feeling that the expansion will be tentative.
articles.abstract: The report showed a loss of 263,000 jobs last month and reinforced a feeling that the expansion will be tentative.
articles.lead_paragraph: After several months in which the American economy flashed tentative signs of improvement, a sobering report on the national job market released on Friday amplified worries that a lengthy period of lean times lay ahead.

articles.headline: Letterman Extortion Raises Questions for CBS
articles.snippet: The network will have to consider whether David Letterman’s actions constituted sexual harassment.
articles.abstract: The network will have to consider whether David Letterman’s actions constituted sexual harassment.
articles.lead_paragraph: If this happened to anyone else, it would just be a punch line.
articles.byline: By Bill Carter and Brian Stelter
